title: Frontline USA: Cuban Americans 2008 03 08 (Al-Jazeera) SoS avi
description:
Frontline USA: Cuban Americans 2008 03 08 (Al-Jazeera) SoS avi		

22.27 min
96.5 mgs

 
This week Frontline USA travels to Miami, Florida and Havana, Cuba to look at the disproportionate power that the Cuban American vote has over a US presidential election.

Fidel Castro may have stepped down and his younger brother Raul has taken his place, but in Miami&#039;s Cuban American community, little has changed.

As an ethnic and ideological group, they have carved out significant influence in Washington.

Donations to political groups and politicians are the second highest in the country, after the Jewish pro-Israel lobby.

A key achievement of all the lobbying - an economic embargo that Washington has maintained against Cuba since 1962.

The embargo was supposed to bring down the Castro government, but it has failed.

The real effect of the embargo has been extreme poverty for ordinary Cubans.

The Cuban influence is not only due to financial contributions - the state of Florida is a swing state, with a large number of electoral delegates.

The way a few voters behave can have a big impact in a presidential election.
